semantic_identifier: 1147756 - Zenith Lark Ventures - sales_call - Discussion with Kinsley Daniels

hierarchy.meeting_title: 1147756 - Zenith Lark Ventures - sales_call - Discussion with Kinsley Daniels

sections.text: Arjun Mehta: Hey Kinsley, good to see you again. Thanks for making the time—last time you mentioned you were trying to tighten your ICP and get cleaner messaging between SMB and mid-market. I wanted to use today to show how Customer_Analyzer would actually score your segments and then turn that into practical positioning you can use on landing pages and outbound. Sound good?
Kinsley Daniels: Hi Arjun. Yep, that’s the goal. We’ve got interest, but we’re still trying to figure out whether this would be actionable for us or just another dashboard.

Arjun Mehta: Totally fair. Let me start with the piece you reacted to last time—our fit estimation. Customer_Analyzer ingests signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding surveys, product usage events, support tickets—and computes a fit score from 0 to 100 at both the account and segment level. Then it breaks down the score so you can see which drivers are pushing it up or down—industry, size, problem severity, time-to-value, adoption patterns, support burden, churn risk signals.
Kinsley Daniels: The fit score is what caught my attention, but it’s also what worries me. A lot of these tools feel like a black box. We get a number, but no one trusts it, and then nothing changes.

Arjun Mehta: That’s the most common concern, and it’s valid. The way we address that is the driver breakdown and evidence trail. So instead of “Mid-market is 82, SMB is 61,” you’ll see: mid-market scores higher because time-to-value is shorter, activation is faster by week two, support tickets per account are lower, and retention is higher. And you can click into the underlying signals that created that—fields, usage events, support tags—so it’s not just magic.

Kinsley Daniels: Okay, but “click into underlying signals” can still be fuzzy. Like, who decides what weights matter? And are we basically training it on our own historical bias? If we’ve historically sold more to mid-market, it’ll tell us mid-market is better, right?

Arjun Mehta: Good question. You can choose fit drivers and adjust them—so you’re not stuck with one rigid model. And we compare segments based on outcomes you care about—conversion, retention, expansion. The recommended ICP profile is based on observed performance, not just volume. If you want to test a growth hypothesis—say “SMB could be great if we change onboarding”—you can configure the drivers to reflect that and see how the score changes as new data comes in.

Kinsley Daniels: That sounds like more work than we have bandwidth for. We’re a lean team. Also, our data isn’t clean. CRM fields are inconsistent, product events are decent, support data is messy. I’m not sure the output would be reliable.

Arjun Mehta: Understood. We typically start lightweight. For your use case—segment-specific messaging for SMB vs mid-market—you don’t need perfect data. We can start with the highest-signal inputs: a handful of CRM fields, a few activation and adoption events, and a couple support categories. Then you get a segment comparison and a fit score with a breakdown that’s “good enough” to guide messaging.

Kinsley Daniels: But then we’re back to trust. If it’s “good enough,” how do I convince my head of sales to change outbound messaging based on it? They’re going to ask, “Why should we believe this score?”

Arjun Mehta: What I’d propose is we treat it as a pilot with a clear validation loop. We take your last 6–12 months of customers, score them, and check whether high-fit accounts correlate with retention or expansion. If it lines up, it earns credibility. If it doesn’t, we revisit the drivers. That way you’re not asking the team to take it on faith.
Kinsley Daniels: A pilot is fine in theory, but we’ve done “pilots” before. They turn into integration projects. What does setup actually look like?

Arjun Mehta: Setup can be as simple as connecting your CRM and importing a CSV for anything else to start. Then we map key fields—industry, employee count, segment, stage—and choose a small set of drivers. For product usage, we can take a few events around activation and adoption. You’d have an initial segment fit comparison in a couple weeks.

Kinsley Daniels: “A couple weeks” is already a lot for us right now. We’re trying to launch a new landing page in three weeks. I don’t think we can afford a tooling project that might or might not change the copy.

Arjun Mehta: If the landing page timeline is tight, we can narrow the scope further. The immediate win could be: get a driver-based comparison between SMB and mid-market and generate positioning recommendations—value props, differentiators, proof points, objection handling—for each. Even if you only use it as a hypothesis generator, it can speed up your messaging work.

Kinsley Daniels: The positioning recommendations part is the other thing I’m skeptical about. We already have messaging docs. A tool telling us “here are differentiators” tends to produce generic stuff. And if it’s derived from messy inputs, it might be confidently wrong.

Arjun Mehta: I hear you. The recommendations are only as good as the signals. What makes ours different is it’s grounded in what your best customers actually do—what features they adopt, what problems show up in onboarding surveys, what objections appear in support tickets. So instead of generic messaging, you’ll get things like: “Mid-market responds to faster time-to-value and lower support overhead,” with suggested proof points pulled from your outcomes.
Kinsley Daniels: But do you actually pull proof points? Because we don’t have neatly labeled “proof points.” And we can’t share sensitive customer details in a SaaS tool without legal review.

Arjun Mehta: We can keep it aggregated and anonymized—no need to expose individual customer names. Proof points can be phrased as patterns: “accounts in this segment reach activation in X days,” “support tickets drop after week Y,” things like that. And we’re used to working with security and legal to define what’s acceptable.
Kinsley Daniels: That’s another blocker. Security and legal here take forever. If the value is “maybe we get better messaging,” it’s hard to justify kicking off that process right now.
Arjun Mehta: Understood. Let me ask—what would make this a “yes” for you? Is it faster time to insight, stronger validation, or a smaller footprint to start?

Kinsley Daniels: Honestly, it’s the trust and effort tradeoff. If we put time into integrating and then the output is a score people argue about, we’ll have wasted a quarter. And our leadership is already wary of “AI scoring” anything.

Arjun Mehta: That makes sense. What if we do an offline evaluation first—no integrations—where you share a sanitized export: segment, basic firmographics, a couple usage metrics, and outcomes like retention or expansion. We run a fit estimation analysis and come back with a segment comparison and driver breakdown. If it passes your smell test, then we talk about connecting systems.

Kinsley Daniels: That’s closer, but even exports take time and approvals. And we’re not convinced the output will be stable enough to bet messaging on. Plus, our segments aren’t just SMB vs mid-market; they’re messy—by use case, by maturity, by region. I don’t want a simplistic model.

Arjun Mehta: We can definitely go beyond SMB vs mid-market and incorporate use case or maturity as drivers. The reason I started with those two is because you called them out as your immediate landing page split, but we can segment however you need.

Kinsley Daniels: I get that. But what I’m hearing is: we’d need to define drivers, debate weights, clean data, and then socialize a score internally. That’s a lot. Right now I need something that helps us ship the page and improve outbound next month, not an analytics initiative.

Arjun Mehta: If speed is the priority, one alternative is we focus purely on the messaging outputs—positioning recommendations—based on a minimal input set. But I don’t want to oversell that if you’re concerned about the foundations.
Kinsley Daniels: Yeah. Without confidence in the fit logic, I can’t sell the messaging recommendations internally. It becomes “the tool said so,” and that won’t fly here.

Arjun Mehta: Fair. Would it help if we scoped a very tight success criterion? For example: “Can Customer_Analyzer predict churn risk difference between two segments,” or “Can it explain why mid-market converts better,” with a simple driver breakdown. If it can’t, you walk away.

Kinsley Daniels: Maybe, but I’m not sure we’re prioritizing this enough to even do that. We’ve got a couple other initiatives ahead of it, and my team is already stretched. I don’t want to commit to something and then go dark.
Arjun Mehta: I appreciate the candor. Last question—do you want me to follow up later in the quarter, or should we close the loop for now?

Kinsley Daniels: Let’s pause for now. If we get through the launch and still feel like we need a more rigorous ICP and messaging engine, I’ll reach out. But I can’t take on integration or internal persuasion work right now.

Arjun Mehta: Got it. I’ll send a short recap of what we discussed—fit estimation, driver breakdown, and how we’d validate it—so you have it handy if priorities shift. And if you want, I can also share a one-page example of the segment comparison output so you can show leadership without committing to anything.
Kinsley Daniels: That’s fine. Send the example. But yeah—no next steps yet.
Arjun Mehta: Understood. Thanks, Kinsley. I’ll get that over to you today, and we’ll stay in touch when timing is better.
Kinsley Daniels: Thanks, Arjun. Talk later.
